subject: Languages
title: Simplified vs. Traditional Chinese Characters
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Simplified vs. Traditional Chinese Characters.

hook.text: China simplified its characters in the 1950s. Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macau refused. Both systems survive.

buildup.text: The Communist government reduced stroke counts to boost literacy â€” 'dragon' went from 16 strokes to 5.

discovery.text: Simplified characters helped China's literacy rate jump from about 20% to over 95% in decades.

twist.text: Critics say simplification destroyed visual logic â€” the character for 'love' lost the 'heart' radical inside it.

climax.text: Today, mainland Chinese read simplified. Taiwan reads traditional. Both sides struggle to read the other.

punchline.text: China simplified writing to unite the country. It created a new divide instead.

quiz.question: Why did China simplify its characters?
options: To increase literacy rates by reducing stroke counts
